com.arjuna.CosTransactions
Class OTS_ResourceRecord

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.arjuna.ArjunaCore.Atomic.StateManager
        |
        +--com.arjuna.ArjunaCore.Atomic.AbstractRecord
              |
              +--com.arjuna.CosTransactions.OTS_ResourceRecord
public class OTS_ResourceRecord
extends AbstractRecord

Arjuna abstract record to handle CORBA (SubtransactionAware)Resource interface. The OTS handling of Resources is bizarre (by Arjuna standards) and confusing Our current understanding is: Resources registered using 'register_resource' ONLY take part in top-level events SubtransactionAwareResources registered using 'register_subtran_aware' ONLY take part in commit/abort of the action in which they are registered - i.e. they DO NOT propagate automatically - the registering object must do the propagation itself using the parent arg in the 'commit_subtransaction' operation. If a SubtransactionAwareResource is registered with 'register_resource' then it will be propagated to the parent when the action commit. Otherwise it is only registered with the current transaction. Subtransactions do not have a 'prepare' phase which can thus lead to inconsistency. If they underwent the full 2-phase protocol (as they do in Arjuna), then all nested participants will have to repond successfully to prepare before they can be told to commit. The way the OTS mandates the protocol, we could tell some to commit before being told by another resource that it cannot commit! We then have to go through the resources and tell them to abort! May cause heuristic decisions! The only problem is if a resource which does not propagate causes a nested action to fail. SubtransactionAwareResources registered using 'register_resource' do appear to propagate. UGH! Braindead!

Since:
JTS 1.0.

Constructor
Parameters:
propagate - tells us whether to propagate the resource at nested commit or not.
theResource - is the proxy that allows us to call out to the object.
myParent - is the proxy for the parent coordinator needed in commit_subtransaction.

nestedAbort

public int nestedAbort()
General nesting rules: Only SubtransactionAware resources get registered with nested actions. The OTS_ResourceRecord creator is assumed to ensure that plain Resources are only registered with the appropriate top level action. That said the _propagateRecord flag ensures that resources registered via register_subtran only take part in the action they where registered in after which they are dropped
Overrides:
nestedAbort in class AbstractRecord
Following copied from class: com.arjuna.ArjunaCore.Atomic.AbstractRecord
Returns:
PrepareOutcome to indicate success/failure.
See Also:
PrepareOutcome

nestedCommit

public int nestedCommit()
If this resource handles nesting this was done in prepare or it should be ignored. In either case returning FINISH_OK suffices.
Overrides:
nestedCommit in class AbstractRecord
Following copied from class: com.arjuna.ArjunaCore.Atomic.AbstractRecord
Returns:
PrepareOutcome to indicate success/failure.
See Also:
PrepareOutcome

nestedPrepare

public int nestedPrepare()
OTS does not use nested prepare at all! However, to make nested commit/abort clean we do commit_subtransaction here. Note that we only get a prepare from Arjuna if the action is to be committed so this is safe in Arjuna terms.
Overrides:
nestedPrepare in class AbstractRecord
Following copied from class: com.arjuna.ArjunaCore.Atomic.AbstractRecord
Returns:
PrepareOutcome to indicate success/failure.

restore_state

public boolean restore_state(InputObjectState os,
                             int t)
restore_state and save_state for OTS_ResourceRecords doesn't generally apply due to object pointers. However, we need to save something so we can recover failed transactions. So, rather than insist that all Resources derive from a class which we can guarantee will give us some unique id, we simply rely on string_to_object and object_to_string to be meaningful.
Overrides:
restore_state in class AbstractRecord
Following copied from class: com.arjuna.ArjunaCore.Atomic.AbstractRecord
Returns:
true if successful, false otherwise.
